Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: The store was packed, the line at my register snaking all the way to the back. My hands moved automatically, scanning items and offering practiced smiles, even as a customer in front of me grew increasingly agitated about a coupon that wouldn’t scan. My phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced down—my best friend’s name flashed on the screen. I knew that tone in her voice when I answered: shaky, on the verge of tears. “Can you talk? I just had a huge fight with Alex,” she whispered. My heart twisted. She needed me to listen, to be there, to offer comfort and understanding. But the customer in front of me was tapping their foot, voice rising, demanding my attention. I could feel the eyes of the people in line, expecting me to stay calm, efficient, and friendly. My friend’s voice trembled in my ear, desperate for support, while the customer’s frustration mounted. I stood there, torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, unsure which expectation to meet first.
